intro: Limodorum trifidum, commonly known as the trifid lily or lesser lily of the valley, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Asparagaceae and is characterized by its delicate, bell-shaped flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its leaves are trifid, meaning they are divided into three parts, giving it a distinctive appearance. Limodorum trifidum is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has a long history of use in traditional herbal medicine.
